channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Smuggling Is on the Rise Off Southern California Coast
item.description: As security along the Mexican border has tightened, the waters off Southern California have been teeming with smugglers, as drug cartels seek new avenues to move illicit cargo into the United States.
item.dc:creator: By IAN LOVETT
item.media:credit: Lt. Stewart Sibert/United States Coast Guard, via Reuters
item.media:description: Chief Petty Officer Terrell Horne, 34, was killed last week off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif., when smugglers rammed their 30-foot fishing boat into the small Coast Guard vessel he was on.

item.title: Morsi Extends Compromise to Egyptian Opposition
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt rescinded most of a temporary order elevating his authority, but did not put off a referendum on a draft constitution, a critical opposition demand.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters against President Mohamed Morsi next to a destroyed barricade near the presidential palace in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: Doping at U.S. Tracks Affects Europe’s Taste for Horse Meat
item.description: European consumers of horse meat are increasingly suspicious of a supply chain that they fear contains drugs injected in American racehorses.
item.dc:creator: By JOE DRAPE
item.media:description: The racehorses Canuki, left, and Cactus Cafe were rejected for slaughter after tests showed they had been medicated.

item.title: In the Ashes in Karachi, Evidence of Oversight Failures
item.description: A fire at a factory that was certified as safe killed at least 262 workers, highlighting monitoring flaws.

item.title: A Bittersweet Reunion in Guatemala
item.description: Amy and Rob Carr of Reno, Nev., are among the 4,000 Americans who found themselves stuck in limbo when Guatemala shut down its international adoption program in 2008.

item.title: Cuban Agriculture Struggles Under Creaky Infrastructure
item.description: More Cubans are farming, but because of waste, poor management, policy constraints and other problems, many are actually seeing less food at new private markets.

item.title: Chief Justice in Sri Lanka Is Found Unfit for Office by Panel
item.description: An impeachment committee investigated 5 of 14 charges against Shirani Bandaranayake and found her guilty of three of them, all related to misuse of power and unexplained wealth.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Karzai Implicates Pakistan in Attack on Afghan Spy Chief
item.description: The Afghan president says that the suicide bomber who staged the attack came from Pakistan, with the help of a sophisticated foreign intelligence service.
item.dc:creator: By GRAHAM BOWLEY and SANGAR RAHIMI
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai, above, said that the man who tried to kill Asadullah Khalid, head of the National Directorate of Security, came from Pakistan.

item.title: Khaled Meshal, Hamas Leader, Delivers Defiant Speech at Anniversary Celebration
item.description: Hamas’s political leader vowed to build an Islamic Palestinian state on all the land of Israel, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of Hamas supporters gathered in Gaza City near a large replica of an M-75, a Hamas rocket, that bore the words “Made in Gaza.”

item.title: Shintaro Ishihara, Right-Wing Japanese Politician, Makes Gains
item.description: Shintaro Ishihara, a novelist turned political firebrand, has emerged as a contender for prime minister and promises to restore Japan’s battered national pride.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Shintaro Ishihara, shown in Tokyo in November, is leading a newly formed populist party.

item.title: Italian Premier to Resign After Losing Party’s Support
item.description: Prime Minister Mario Monti announced his plans after his predecessor, Silvio Berlusconi, said he would run again.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Rumblings for Change Within Sudan’s Governing Party
item.description: Younger members representing the Islamist core of the National Congress Party are pushing an agenda of fighting corruption and expanding dialogue with the opposition.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Stalled Adoption Program in Guatemala Leaves Families in Limbo
item.description: Hundreds of children have been stranded in orphanages in Guatemala for years as authorities there weigh whether to approve their adoptions to families in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL L. SWARNS
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy and Rob Carr in Guatemala with Geovany Archilla Rodas, whom they have been trying to adopt since 2007.

item.title: For Afghan Officials, Prospect of Death Comes With Territory
item.description: Afghan government officials do not worry so much about the wrath of constituents as about being assassinated by the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdul Majid Khogyani, center, the governor of Wardak Province, touring government buildings damaged by a suicide truck bombing two days earlier.

item.title: The Lede Blog: After Radio Prank, Hospital Chairman Condemns Australian Network
item.description: After two Australian radio hosts, as a prank, called the London hospital where Kate Middleton was being treated, a nurse who fell victim to the hoax was found dead.
item.dc:creator: By MARC SANTORA

item.title: North Korea Cites Rocket Problems
item.description: Referencing technical issues, North Korea said that it might have to postpone a rocket launching planned for as early as Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Climate Talks Yield Commitment to Ambitious, but Unclear, Actions
item.description: Delegates agreed to extend the increasingly ineffective Kyoto Protocol and other unspecified actions to reduce emissions of climate-altering gases.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By JOHN M. BRODER
item.media:description: Bard Vegar Solhjell, Norway’s environmental minister, with protesters on Saturday.

item.title: Russia Announces Barriers on Imports of U.S. Meat
item.description: The move was seen by some analysts as retaliation for American legislation punishing Russian officials linked to human rights violations.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Syrian Rebels Tied to Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
item.description: The United States faces a challenge, as some of the best fighters in uprising that it wants to support belong to a group that it considers a terrorist organization.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Changes to Agriculture Highlight Cuba’s Problems
item.description: Although the government has liberalized many aspects of agriculture, inefficiencies caused by central control mean the food situation has gotten worse in some ways.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: Planting potatoes near Güira de Melena, a productive region not far from Havana. Much farming in Cuba remains low-tech because of a lack of machinery.

item.title: The Lede Blog: Updates on Protests in Egypt
item.description: The Lede is following the political crisis in Egypt, where supporters and opponents of President Mohamed Morsi rallied on Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and LIAM STACK

item.title: Nurse’s Death Stirs Sharp Criticism of Royal Prank Call
item.description: A nurse tricked by Australian D.J.’s who called posing as Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles to get information about Kate Middleton’s pregnancy was found dead on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: The Human Price: Pakistan Factory Fire Shows Flaws in Monitoring
item.description: Retail giants have helped create and champion numerous factory inspection systems, but industry-backed auditing was no protection for at least 262 Pakistanis who died in a September blaze.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker in a burned textile factory in Karachi, Pakistan. At least 262 workers died in the blaze. The factory passed inspection before the fire.

item.title: Afghan Leader Says Attack on Spy Chief Was Planned in Pakistan
item.description: Afghan President Hamid Karzai said on Saturday a suicide bombing that wounded his intelligence chief was planned in the Pakistani city of Quetta and that the issue would be raised with Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Afghan President Hamid Karzai spoke at a news conference in Kabul on Saturday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Romany Were European 500 Years Earlier Than Previously Thought
item.description: A study offers new details on the history of the Romany people in Europe since their ancestors left India. A millennium and a half on, their descendants are still victims of prejudice but some are fighting back.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Mourners attended the funeral of a Romany father and son murdered in Hungary in 2009.
